io.hekate.metrics.local

Interface LocalMetricsService

  • All Superinterfaces:
    MetricsSource, Service

    @DefaultServiceFactory(value=LocalMetricsServiceFactory.class)
public interface LocalMetricsService
extends Service, MetricsSource
    « start hereMain entry point to node-local metrics API.

    Overview

    This service provides support for managing metrics of a running Hekate node with ability to dynamically register custom application-specific metrics. The following types of metrics are supported by this service:

    • Counters - metrics with incrementing/decrementing values.
    • Probes - metrics that obtain their values from some third-party source.
    • Timers - for tracking durations of arbitrary events.

    All metrics that are registered within this service can be exposed to remote cluster nodes with the help of ClusterMetricsService. Please see its documentation for more details.

    Service configuration

    Metrics service can be configured and registered in HekateBootstrap with the help of LocalMetricsServiceFactory as shown in the example below:

    • Java
    • Spring XSD
    • Spring bean
    
// Prepare service factory.
LocalMetricsServiceFactory factory = new LocalMetricsServiceFactory()
    // Set metrics refresh interval to 1 second.
    .withRefreshInterval(1000)
    // Register counter.
    .withMetric(new CounterConfig("example.counter"))
    // Register timer.
    .withMetric(new TimerConfig("example.timer"))
    // Register probe.
    .withMetric(new ProbeConfig()
        .withName("cpu.count")
        .withProbe(() -> Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors())
    );

// Start node.
Hekate hekate = new HekateBootstrap()
    .withService(factory)
    .join();
    Note: This example requires Spring Framework integration (see HekateSpringBootstrap). 
    
<beans xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:h="http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core"
    xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd
        http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core
        http://www.hekate.io/spring/hekate-core.xsd">

    <h:node id="hekate">
        <!-- Local metrics service. -->
        <h:local-metrics refresh-interval-ms="1000">
            <h:counters>
                <!-- Example counter. -->
                <h:counter name="example.counter"/>
            </h:counters>
            <h:probes>
                <!-- Example probe. -->
                <h:probe name="example.probe">
                    <bean class="foo.bar.SomeProbe"/>
                </h:probe>
            </h:probes>
        </h:local-metrics>

        <!-- ...other services... -->
    </h:node>
</beans>
    Note: This example requires Spring Framework integration (see HekateSpringBootstrap). 
    
<beans xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">

    <bean id="hekate" class="io.hekate.spring.bean.HekateSpringBootstrap">
        <property name="services">
            <list>
                <!-- Local metrics service. -->
                <bean class="io.hekate.metrics.local.LocalMetricsServiceFactory">
                    <property name="refreshInterval" value="1000"/>
                    <property name="metrics">
                        <list>
                            <!-- Example counter. -->
                            <bean class="io.hekate.metrics.local.CounterConfig">
                                <property name="name" value="example.counter"/>
                            </bean>
                            <!-- Example probe. -->
                            <bean class="io.hekate.metrics.local.ProbeConfig">
                                <property name="name" value="example.probe"/>
                                <property name="probe">
                                    <bean class="foo.bar.SomeProbe"/>
                                </property>
                            </bean>
                        </list>
                    </property>
                </bean>

                <!-- ...other services... -->
            </list>
        </property>
    </bean>
</beans>

    For all available configuration options please see the documentation of LocalMetricsServiceFactory class.

    Accessing service

    Metrics service can be accessed via Hekate.localMetrics() method as in the example below: 

    
LocalMetricsService metrics = hekate.localMetrics();

    Counters

    Counters are typically used to track custom application statistics like the amount of processed transactions, active connections or service requests. Basically everything that can be represented as a dynamically increasing (or decreasing) value falls into the category of counter metrics.

    Counters can be registered within the LocalMetricsService either at configuration time or dynamically at runtime. Once registered they can be accessed via the counter(String) method.

    Configuration of each counter is represented by the CounterConfig class with the following key properties:

    • Metric name - unique name of the counter;
    • Auto-reset - enabled/disables auto-resetting of the counter to its default value after every refresh interval;

    For more information about configuration options please see the documentation of CounterConfig class.

    The code example below illustrates the basic usage of counter for tracking task executions in some imaginary service: 

    
public class CounterExampleService {
    private final CounterMetric tasks;

    public CounterExampleService(Hekate hekate) {
        // Register counter.
        tasks = hekate.localMetrics().register(new CounterConfig()
            .withName("task.active")
            .withTotalName("task.total")
        );
    }

    public void processTask(Runnable task) {
        // Increment before starting the task.
        tasks.increment();

        try {
            // Run some long and heavy task.
            task.run();
        } finally {
            // Decrement once tasks is completed.
            tasks.decrement();
        }
    }
}

    ... and access those values in some other components of the program: 

    
System.out.println("Active tasks: " + hekate.localMetrics().get("task.active"));
System.out.println(" Total tasks: " + hekate.localMetrics().get("task.total"));

    Probes

    Probes provide metrics based on periodic polling of some third-party sources. Examples of such sources are current CPU utilization, memory consumption or availability status of some service.

    Probes can be registered within the LocalMetricsService either at configuration time or dynamically at runtime.

    Configuration of each probe is represented by the ProbeConfig class with the following key properties:

    • Metric name - unique name of the probe;
    • Probe - implementation of Probe interface that is responsible for obtaining the probe value from the third-party source;
    • Initial value - (optional) initial value that the probe should start with;

    For more information about configuration options please see the documentation of ProbeConfig class.

    Once probe is registered, LocalMetricsService will start polling it in order to obtain and cache the latest value. Polling interval is controlled by the LocalMetricsServiceFactory.setRefreshInterval(long) configuration option.

    The code example below illustrates the basic implementation of the Probe interface: 

    
// Register probe that will provide the amount of free memory in the JVM.
hekate.localMetrics().register(new ProbeConfig("memory.free")
    .withProbe(() -> Runtime.getRuntime().freeMemory())
);

    Timers

    Timers measure the amount of time (in nanoseconds) it takes to process an arbitrary operation and can optionally provide a rate of that operation per refresh interval.

    Timers can be registered within the LocalMetricsService either statically or dynamically. Once registered they can be accessed via the timer(String) method.

    Configuration of each timer is represented by the TimerConfig class with the following key properties:

    • Timer metric name - unique name of the timer;
    • Rate metric name - (optional) name of a metric that will hold the rate value of this timer;

    For more information about configuration options please see the documentation of TimerConfig class.

    The following code example shows the basic use of a timer to track the time/rate of execution in some imaginary service: 

    
public class TimerExampleService {
    private final TimerMetric timer;

    public TimerExampleService(Hekate hekate) {
        // Register timer.
        timer = hekate.localMetrics().register(new TimerConfig()
            .withName("task.time")
            .withRateName("task.rate")
            .withTimeUnit(TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)
        );
    }

    public void processTask(Runnable task) {
        try (TimeSpan time = timer.start()) {
            // Run the task.
            task.run();
        }
    }
}

    ... and access those values in some other components of the program: 

    
System.out.println("Task time: " + hekate.localMetrics().get("task.time"));
System.out.println("Task rate: " + hekate.localMetrics().get("task.rate"));

    Accessing metrics

    LocalMetricsService extends the MetricsSource interface which provides methods for accessing all registered metrics by their names.

    Another approach for accessing metrics is to register an instance of MetricsListener interface. Such listener will be notified once per refresh interval with a snapshot of metric values. Below is the example of simple listener that prints out metrics from previous examples: 

    
// Listen for metrics updates.
hekate.localMetrics().addListener(event -> {
    System.out.println("Free memory: " + event.get("memory.free"));
    System.out.println("Active tasks: " + event.get("task.active"));
    System.out.println("Total tasks: " + event.get("task.total"));
});

    Default metrics

    By default the following metrics are available out of the box:

    • jvm.mem.used - The amount of memory in megabytes used by the JVM
    • jvm.mem.committed - The amount of memory in megabytes that is committed for the JVM to use
    • jvm.mem.free - The amount of memory in megabytes that is available to the JVM
    • jvm.mem.max - The maximum amount of memory in megabytes that the JVM will attempt to use
    • jvm.mem.heap.committed - The amount of heap memory in megabytes that is committed for the JVM to use
    • jvm.mem.heap.used - The amount of heap memory in megabytes used by the JVM
    • jvm.mem.nonheap.committed - The amount of non-heap memory in megabytes that is committed for the JVM to use
    • jvm.mem.nonheap.used - The amount of non-heap memory in megabytes used by the JVM
    • jvm.threads.live - The current number of live threads including both daemon and non-daemon threads
    • jvm.threads.daemon - The current number of live daemon threads
    • jvm.cpu.count - The the number of processors available to the JVM
    • jvm.cpu.load - The system CPU load average in percents (0-100) for the last minute or -1 if such metric is not supported by the JVM.

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addListener(MetricsListener listener)
      Registers the specified listener.
      CounterMetric counter(String name)
      Returns a counter for the specified name or register a new counter with the default configuration if there is no such counter.
      long refreshInterval()
      Returns the configuration value of LocalMetricsServiceFactory.getRefreshInterval().
      CounterMetric register(CounterConfig config)
      Registers a new counter with the specified configuration or returns an existing one if counter with the same name already exists.
      Metric register(ProbeConfig config)
      Registers a probe with the specified configuration.
      TimerMetric register(TimerConfig config)
      Registers a new timer with the specified configuration or returns an existing one if timer with the same name already exists.
      void removeListener(MetricsListener listener)
      Unregisters the specified listener.
      MetricsSnapshot snapshot()
      Returns an immutable snapshot of metrics that were aggregated by this service.
      TimerMetric timer(String name)
      Returns a timer for the specified name or register a new timer with the default configuration if there is no such timer.

    • Method Detail

      • snapshot

        MetricsSnapshot snapshot()
        Returns an immutable snapshot of metrics that were aggregated by this service.

        Note that snapshots get aggregated once per LocalMetricsServiceFactory.setRefreshInterval(long).

        Returns:
        Metrics snapshot.

      • register

        CounterMetric register(CounterConfig config)
        Registers a new counter with the specified configuration or returns an existing one if counter with the same name already exists. If there is another metric of a different type then an error will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        config - Counter configuration.
        Returns:
        Counter.

      • register

        TimerMetric register(TimerConfig config)
        Registers a new timer with the specified configuration or returns an existing one if timer with the same name already exists. If there is another metric of a different type then an error will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        config - Timer configuration.
        Returns:
        Timer.

      • register

        Metric register(ProbeConfig config)
        Registers a probe with the specified configuration. If there is another metric with the same name then an error will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        config - Probe configuration.
        Returns:
        Metric for the new newly created probe.

      • counter

        CounterMetric counter(String name)
        Returns a counter for the specified name or register a new counter with the default configuration if there is no such counter.
        Parameters:
        name - Counter name (see MetricConfigBase.setName(String)).
        Returns:
        Counter.

      • timer

        TimerMetric timer(String name)
        Returns a timer for the specified name or register a new timer with the default configuration if there is no such timer.
        Parameters:
        name - Timer name (see MetricConfigBase.setName(String)).
        Returns:
        Timer.

      • addListener

        void addListener(MetricsListener listener)
        Registers the specified listener.

        Listener will be notified once per LocalMetricsServiceFactory.getRefreshInterval().

        Note: listeners are notified on the same thread that performs metrics management and hence should process notifications as fast as possible. If notification processing is a time consuming task then it is highly recommended to offload such task to some other thread and process it asynchronously.

        Parameters:
        listener - Listener.

      • removeListener

        void removeListener(MetricsListener listener)
        Unregisters the specified listener.
        Parameters:
        listener - Listener.

      • refreshInterval

        long refreshInterval()
        Returns the configuration value of LocalMetricsServiceFactory.getRefreshInterval().
        Returns:
        Value of LocalMetricsServiceFactory.getRefreshInterval().
